# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is the Julia code for solving the problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s) # Split string into words
    lines = Any[]
    current_line = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line * " $word") > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = "$word"
        else
            current_line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)  # add the last line if not added yet
    
    return join(lines, '\n')
end
```
This function iterates through each word in the input string `s` and checks if adding it to the current line would exceed the text width. If so, it adds that line to the list of lines (the result), and starts a new line with just this word. If not, it simply adds the word to the current line.

Here is an example usage:
```julia
s = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit"
print(wrap_string(s))
```
This will print a string where each new line starts with "Lorem", "ipsum", etc., and the rest of the words continue on subsequent lines.
